From above, its myriad of cobbled streets and intricate piazzas form a detailed map of stories, like the lines formed on a grandmother’s hands. Look a little closer, and visitors will soon find that Trastevere is brimming with a unique mix of bars, restaurants, and sights certain to appeal. Wedged between the Tiber river, the Vatican, and Janiculum Hill, Trastevere truly is in the thick of it all! Split into two distinct sides of Viale Trastevere, visitors can find their ideal patch of splendour. On the Santa Maria in Trastevere side, tourists and international students mingle in and out of well-priced pubs and tavernas. On the other side of Viale Trastevere, to the south, a genuine Roman spirit breathes amidst cobbled streets and traditional osterie.<br />Being one of the main Roman hubs, Trastevere is always full of life. COL name VAL CASA della SALITA COL description VAL Our apartment is in an old and charming building, in the San Pietro district. It is a characteristic part of old Rome, very close to St. Peter's Basilica (6 minutes on foot). The neighborhood is quiet and allows you to enjoy your stay in a relaxing way. The apartment is perfect for 2 adults. Nearby there are plenty of shops, supermarkets (open all night), pizzerias, restaurants, pharmacies. There is also a good outdoor market where you can buy fresh fruit and vegetables from Roman farmers.<br /><br /><b>The space</b><br />The apartment is simple, about 40 square meters and has everything you need for a stay. My advice is to avoid shopping and cooking, if you have no special dietary needs or children. It is therefore recommended the responsible use of anti-Covid19 security devices and the maintenance of the safety distance of at least 1 mete COL neighborhood_overview VAL The villa overlooks the protected area of the Valle dei Casali which looks like a green corridor within the urban area that extends from Villa Pamphili in the north, to the shores of the Tiber in the south. The reserve is characterized by a plateau that reaches 80 meters and then slopes down to the level of the river with a course of rolling hills. The vegetation is the result of the predominantly agricultural land use, the presence of a dense network of ditches, the Tiber River and the proximity with urbanized areas of the city. The valley creeps from the southwest into the urban fabric representing a wedge of greenery that connects the broad coastal floodplains with the city center. The main interest of the area lies in the conservation of a system of villas and farmhouses. Of great interest is the eighteenth-century Villa York, near which stands the monumental structure of the Good Shepherd. A washing machine and hair dryer are also av COL neighborhood_overview VAL TIME OUT:<br />Great things to do in Rome: Tease your tastebuds at Il Pigneto.<br />In the last couple of years Il Pigneto, just east of Porta Maggiore, has achieved that critical mass of bars and restaurants that turns a below-the-radar district hip. It's a mix of houses and low-rise 1960s condominiums, whose proximity to the San Lorenzo stockyards meant that the area suffered heavy wartime bombing. But the anarchic, bohemian feel of the place attracted arty types such as Pier Paolo Pasolini, who shot his first film here.<br />9/03/14 THE NEW YORK TIMES: <br />" Pigneto feels a world away from Rome’s tourist herds and ancient ruins. A 10-minute bus ride from the arterial Termini station, Pigneto, Rome’s answer to Bushwick, Brooklyn, is an enclave of cool in the eternal city". First of all because it was built as a residential area for factory and railways workers, second and most important because it was heavily damaged by a WWII bombing.<br />It was the heaviest bombing Rome suffered during WWII. 1,500 people died, 4,000 were injured. Most of the buildings were destroyed. Reconstruction had to be fast and cheap as it was the case all over Italy in the war aftermath.<br />How did it become Rome’s student and young artist district? We are based in the lively, non-touristy and university district of San Lorenzo, with Termini station 1.2 km away, around 15 minutes walk away. The area can give you some of the local flavor of Rome, it’s full of many good restaurants where locals dine and there’s easy access to the public transportation. <br /><br />The flat has recently been refurbished preserving the original arches and exposed brick vaults, with the addition of a few personal touches. We have created a warm and welcoming ambience, which we hope gives our guests a unique and personalized holiday experien COL neighborhood_overview VAL San Lorenzo, given its proximity to La Sapienza University, is one of the liveliest and most characteristic neighborhoods in Rome.  It is an area brimming with culture and art, with streets full of art galleries and workshops, cafes, clubs, supermarkets and a variety of shops. You may be lucky enough to watch some artists working on their crafts and be captivated by the vibrant atmosphere around the streets of our neighborhood. At lunch and dinner, you'll be spoilt for choice, with many options at your disposal: street food, Roman cuisine, vegan dishes, international cuisine, to name but a few! Experience the many cultural and entertainment opportunities: watch a film in a tiny peculiar movie house, visit an art exhibition in the Pastificio Cerere, eat a delicious pastry in the Ancient chocolate factory, have a coffee in a bookstore or visit the ancient San Lorenzo's basilica and the Verano monumental cemetery! The choices are never ending! Decidedly local in demeanor, San Giovanni's modern avenues open out onto unexpectedly ornate cathedrals, its food scene is centered on community produce markets rather than restaurants, and entertainment happens in parks rather than clubs. San Giovanni invites modern Romans to compare and contrast the pages of history with the amenities of the present day. There is also the convenience of shops and food stalls open until late at night. When the sun drives away the night, the pedestrian area becomes the home of the local market. Questa, simbolo dello Stato del Vaticano, è la più grande delle quattro basiliche papali di Roma. Consiglio, agli amanti delle camminate, di intraprendere una piacevole passeggiata di circa 26 minuti per raggiungerla così da godere al meglio delle bellezze architettoniche e culturali che incontrerai lungo il tragitto come: la Chiesa di Santa Maria delle Grazie alle Fornaci, edificata nel XV secolo; Largo di Porta Cavalleggeri, dove risiedeva l'omonima porta ed, infine, Piazza San Pietro antistante la basilica omonima. La celeberrima piazza, notevole esempio di architettura ed urbanistica barocca, è dedicata all'omonimo santo ed è un quotidiano punto d'incontro per migliaia di fedeli cattolici provenienti da tutto il mondo. Rione means small quarter, the name ‘Monti’ literally means mountains in Italian and comes from the fact that the Esquiline and the Viminal Hills, and parts of the Quirinal and the Caelian Hills belonged to this rione. Its logo consists of three green mountains with three tops on a silver background. Today the Esquilino, Castro Pretorio and Celio districts do not belong to it anymore, but it has kept its name. <br />Nowadays this area is famous for its quiet during the day,the large number of excellent restaurants and pizzerias and the proverbial friendliness of its inhabitants. The night the quarter becomes one of the major destinations of the Rome by night, so it is an ideal place to discover the vitality of the city. A historical, artistic and cultural base offering privileged guests the highlights of the city within walking distance.<br />Named after the nearby Spanish Embassy, the Spanish Steps have been in Rome since 1723. They connect the Piazza di Spagna at the bottom with Piazza Trinita dei Monti at the top. Located on the eastern side of the old city center, there are a lot of interesting places to see in the area.<br />There are a total of 138 steps to climb, but if you aren’t sure whether or not you can make it, consider taking the lift which is right next to the metro station.<br />The Spanish Steps are typically used as a meeting place where people will relax and take a break. <br />Visitors will find several shops at the base and usually a few artists at the top providing portraits for tourists. The name of the street comes from the presence on it of workshops for craftsmen and shops selling more or less valuable so-called bodices of cloth. The artisans and vendors were called gipponari, in Latin jupponarii, this is actually the profession where the name of the street derives from. In our days, along the street, the visitors can find a high variety of shops, ovens for bread, pastries, including the famous pastry bar "Bernasconi" located right next to the entrance of the apartment. COL neighborhood_overview VAL What to see in the Trastevere<br />The life of the neighbourhood is especially concentrated around the Piazza di Santa Maria in Trastevere, where you can see the ancient Basilica of Our Lady in Trastevere. The great fountain in front of the temple serves as a meeting place, a resting spot, or simply somewhere to have an ice cream on a hot day.<br /><br />A walk through the narrow cobbled streets of the Trastevere shows hidden treasures such as modest medieval churches, small shops with the most unusual objects, or even some scenes of everyday life seemingly taken from a forgotten age.<br /><br />Traditional Roman Cuisine<br />The Trastevere is one of the best areas for dining in Rome making it very pleasant for a walk through its streets, especially as night falls and the time for supper approaches.<br /><br />Visitors seeking the most traditional bars, and those who prefer more modern and innovative venues will all find the perfect spot in the Trastevere. COL neighborhood_overview VAL The Termini district is the headquarters of Rome's main train station. Here there are continuous connections to and from airports and cities throughout Italy. The area is very central: you can walk all the city's tourist-cultural routes as well as the shopping streets. The district is lively and heterogeneous: the multiculturalism that reigns through the streets of the neighborhood reminds us that we live in a large European metropolis and this is also reflected in the offer of various restaurants. Here are located many fine restaurants as well as the innovative central market (Website hidden by Airbnb) where the gastronomic quality reigns supreme. If instead you want to experiment with ethnic cuisine, you will be spoiled for choice because the district is full of refreshments of every imaginable origin. For a short or a long stay in the 'eternal city' the choice of the Termini district is the most convenient and practical option. It is the most authentic and characteristic district, the perfect place to glimpse the old world while enjoying the lifestyle of today's Romans. Often described as Bohemian, Trastevere maintains its character thanks to the old, narrow, winding, cobblestone streets. Homes decorated with flower boxes and clinging ivy interlace with coffee bars, restaurants, and one-of-a-kind boutiques.Take a stroll to the lively Piazza Trilussa or to the amazing Piazza di Santa Maria in Trastevere. Crossing Ponte Sisto you can reach within walking distance many astonishing places such as Campo de Fiori, Piazza Navona, the Pantheon, the Imperial Forum, the Coliseum and Spanish Steps. Following the river Tiber for 10 minutes you may reach the Vatican and the Sistine Chapel. COL name VAL Very cute room near metro station COL description VAL Quiet and nice apartment in "Quadraro" 's neighborhood, closed to A line metro's station "Numidio Quadrato" (3 minutes walk!!). In 15/20 minutes you will reach the city center and enjoy Rome. Free Wi-Fi available.<br /><br />Luigi<br /><br /><b>The space</b><br />The apartment (90 sq. meters, ground floor) is located in a small and quiet neighborhood in the very heart of Quadraro. It has a spacious well-equipped kitchen and a nice bathroom. <br />You can easily reach the apartment either you arrive at Ciampino or Fiumicino airport. There are frequent connections from both places. If you arrive at Fiumicino you can take Terravision bus (booking it online is better!!) or the train, and arrive at Termini Station, there you find the underground. Get on Line A (red) metro, direction "Anagnina", and get off at "Numidio Quadrato" (3 minutes walk from our place). For those arriving at Ciampino, you can take Terravision bus to Termini Station, or a shuttle that goes to "Anagnina" metro Station. COL neighborhood_overview VAL Ever since Quadraro's citizens impeded the infiltration of Mussolini and the Germans into their neighborhood, their rebellious spirit has remained unflinching. The neighborhood's residents have developed a tight-knit community that prides itself on maintaining its fiercely independent and self-sufficient nature. Quadraro continues to resist external forces as everyone from real-estate developers to local authorities seeks to tame its unapologetic character and edgy undertones–the same character and undertones that make it a local favorite.<br /><br />Only 300 m. from the apartment, on foot, you find via Tuscolana, one of the main boulevard of the city, that is a commercial zone for clothes and shoes shopping, with the hundreds of small food shops open 'till night selling snacks, fruits, ice-cream, drinks. In the nearby area, there is also a shopping centre at a close distance. Walking another 10 minutes we arrive to Cinecittà Studios, where many fomuos italian films were made. The development of Parione can be associated with three periods:<br />a) the second half of the XVth century with the erection of Palazzo della Cancelleria and the embellishment of Campo de' Fiori;<br />b) the last years of the XVIth century when a very large church, S. Maria in Vallicella, was built in the western tip of Parione;<br />c) the years around 1650 when Piazza Navona was thoroughly redesigned. It is a quiet neighborhood, one of the safest in the capital, but lively and vibrant. Although ancient, it is not touristy and has retained its popular size with cafes, shops, grocery stores. Perfectly connected, it is close to the bus stops to the center and to the station, the taxi, and a few minutes walk to the subway (to ten minutes, the Re di Roma stop, while to a quarter of an hour, the San Giovanni stop, museum-station with inside the archaeological finds that emerged during the excavations who can be visited as a journey through time)<br /><br />A few meters away, there are bars, taverns, supermarkets (even organic), pastry shops, pharmacies, banks and  an indoor pool in the historic Appio Swimming Center.<br />You can have break COL host_id VAL 15514038 COL host_name VAL Michele COL neighbourhood VAL Rome, Lazio, Italy COL neighbourhood_cleansed VAL VII San Giovanni/Cinecittà COL neighbourhood_group_cleansed VAL nan COL latitude VAL 41.87496 COL longitude VAL 12.51219 COL property_type VAL Entire apartment COL room_type VAL Entire home/apt COL accommodates VAL 6 COL bathrooms VAL nan COL bathrooms_text VAL 2 baths COL bedrooms VAL 3.0 COL beds VAL 4.0 COL price VAL $82.00 	COL name VAL ARIA DI MARE  A 20 KM DA ROMA COL description VAL un elegante, , confortevole appartamento con un ampio soggiorno 2 grandi camere matrimoniali 1 camera singola con 2 letti e 2 bagni . For a little high culture, head to the Basilica of San Giovanni and the nearby Scala Santa (Holy Steps) which were supposed to have been the steps that Jesus walked on before his trial with Pontius Pilate and were transferred to Rome from Jerusalem in the 4th century. For a place to enjoy a peaceful walk or a quiet sit down, the Appia Antica Park is an ideal haven away from the noise of the city and is filled with archeological monuments and large trees. The Terme di Caracalla is one of Rome’s most awe-inspiring ruins, with the 1800-year old complex once being Emperor Caracalla’s bath house, gym and library. From above, its myriad of cobbled streets and intricate piazzas form a detailed map of stories, like the lines formed on a grandmother’s hands. Look a little closer, and visitors will soon find that Trastevere is brimming with a unique mix of bars, restaurants, and sights certain to appeal. Wedged between the Tiber river, the Vatican, and Janiculum Hill, Trastevere truly is in the thick of it all! Split into two distinct sides of Viale Trastevere, visitors can find their ideal patch of splendour. On the Santa Maria in Trastevere side, tourists and international students mingle in and out of well-priced pubs and tavernas. On the other side of Viale Trastevere, to the south, a genuine Roman spirit breathes amidst cobbled streets and traditional osterie.<br />Being one of the main Roman hubs, Trastevere is always full of life. The area is rich in monuments, starting with what symbolizes Italy in the world, the Colosseum. Narrow, sometimes tortuous alleyways are highly suggestive and offer the possibility of admiring important archaeological remains. A few meters away you will find the Fori Imperiali, or by climbing the narrow steps of the Salita dei Borgia you will be in San Pietro in Vincoli where Michelangelo's Moses is displayed. First of all because it was built as a residential area for factory and railways workers, second and most important because it was heavily damaged by a WWII bombing.<br />It was the heaviest bombing Rome suffered during WWII. 1,500 people died, 4,000 were injured. Most of the buildings were destroyed. Reconstruction had to be fast and cheap as it was the case all over Italy in the war aftermath.<br />How did it become Rome’s student and young artist district? You should visit it because it’s the house of an interesting mix of older folk who have lived there for decades, wih a new crowd of creative young citizens.<br />Today it’s a vibrant cultural quarter, wine bars and restaurants are the main fare here. There’s a speakeasy here called Spirito (think roulette tables and a rooftop bar that you access from a sandwich shop!) and the Bottiglieria Pigneto is popular with locals. CoHouse is the new kid on the block here. A converted warehouse houses a rotating schedule of chefs and after dinner is an exclusive cocktail bar. <br />Special tip<br />there's a flea market on the fourth Saturday of every month… and do not miss to have a lunch at Necci1924! COL name VAL Casa Stelletta ti aspetta COL description VAL Visitare Roma soggiornando nel cuore della Capitale è oggi un privilegio alla tua portata. Al primo piano di uno stabile d'epoca, ti aspetta un bellissimo e comodissimo appartamento. Casa Stelletta si trova nel cuore della città, a due passi dai principali monumenti e dai palazzi istituzionali. Se sei a Roma, per vacanza o lavoro, potrai disporre di 80 mq con soggiorno, cucina, camera da letto matrimoniale con bagno, seconda camera da letto e secondo bagno con doccia. In tutto 4 posti letto. COL neighborhood_overview VAL Esci al mattino dall'appartamento e già senti il profumo del cappuccino e dei cornetti di Cristian, patron del Caffè Gotico che sta propio in via della Stelletta, appena esci dal portone di casa alla tua destra. Cominci poi la tua escursione, a piedi o con comodi monopattini a noleggio che trovi dappertutto, anche sotto il portone di casa, e vai al Pantheon, Fontana di Trevi, Piazza Venezia, Colosseo, Circo Massimo, Bocca della verità. Ti fermi poi per una pausa pranzo alla Birreria Peroni, in Via di S. Marcello 19, aperta tutti i giorni a pranzo e a cena (no domenica), dove Cesare ti aspetta copi suoi bucatini all'amatriciana o con gli spaghetti cacio e pepe tra i più buoni di tutta la Capitale. Finito di mangiare prosegui il giro per vedere i più bei palazzi istituzionali del mondo: Quirinale, Palazzo Montecitorio, Palazzo Madama. Lì vicino fai una pausa alla Chiesa di San Luigi dei Francesi dove potrai ammirare, tra l'altro, degli splendidi quadri del Caravaggio.
